--- title: Introduction to `pandas` jupyter: python3 --- The `pandas` library (https://pandas.pydata.org) is one of the most used tool at the disposal of people working with data in `python` today. - It allows to **crunch data** easily - It mainly provides a `DataFrame` object (a **table of data**) with a huge set of functionalities ## Why ? Through `pandas`, you get acquainted with your data by **analyzing** it - What's the average, median, max, or min of each column? - Does column A correlate with column B? - What does the distribution of data in column C look like? ## Why (con't) ? you get acquainted with your data by **cleaning** and **transforming** it - Removing missing values, filter rows or columns using some criteria - Store the cleaned, transformed data back into virtually any format or database - Data visualization (when combined `matplotlib` or `seaborn` or others) ## Where ? `pandas` is a central component of the `python` "stack" for data science - `pandas` is built on top of `numpy` - often used in conjunction with other libraries - a `DataFrame` is often fed to plotting functions or machine learning algorithms (such as `scikit-learn`) - Well-interfaced with `jupyter`, leading to a nice interactive environment for data exploration and modeling ## Core components of pandas The two primary components of pandas are the `Series` and `DataFrame`. - A `Series` is essentially a column - A `DataFrame` is a multi-dimensional table made up of a collection of `Series` with equal length ## Creating a `DataFrame` from scratch ::: {#2488510b .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd fruits = { "apples": [3, 2, 0, 1], "oranges": [0, 3, 7, 2] } df_fruits = pd.DataFrame(fruits) df_fruits ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ```{=html}
apples oranges
0 3 0
1 2 3
2 0 7
3 1 2
``` ::: ::: ::: {#e5bcbce1 .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} type(df_fruits) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ``` pandas.core.frame.DataFrame ``` ::: ::: ::: {#49f4cdfd .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_fruits["apples"] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ``` 0 3 1 2 2 0 3 1 Name: apples, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#68772e12 .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} type(df_fruits["apples"]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ``` pandas.core.series.Series ``` ::: ::: ## Indexing - By default, a `DataFrame` uses a contiguous index - But what if we want to say **who** buys the fruits ? ::: {#82c4790b .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_fruits = pd.DataFrame(fruits, index=["Daniel", "Sean", "Pierce", "Roger"]) df_fruits ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ```{=html}
apples oranges
Daniel 3 0
Sean 2 3
Pierce 0 7
Roger 1 2
``` ::: ::: ## `.loc` versus `.iloc` - `.loc` **loc**ates by name - `.iloc` **loc**ates by numerical **i**ndex ::: {#5e895886 .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_fruits ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ```{=html}
apples oranges
Daniel 3 0
Sean 2 3
Pierce 0 7
Roger 1 2
``` ::: ::: ::: {#2e5337c0 .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} # What's in Sean's basket ? df_fruits.loc['Sean'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ``` apples 2 oranges 3 Name: Sean, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#d0641281 .cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Who has oranges ? df_fruits.loc[:, 'oranges'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ``` Daniel 0 Sean 3 Pierce 7 Roger 2 Name: oranges, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#ad391efe .cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} # How many apples in Pierce's basket ? df_fruits.loc['Pierce', 'apples'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=9} ``` np.int64(0) ``` ::: ::: ::: {#0e794420 .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_fruits ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=10} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ::: {#b9239983 .cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_fruits.iloc[2, 1] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ``` np.int64(7) ``` ::: ::: ## Main attributes and methods of a `DataFrame` A `DataFrame` has many **attributes** ::: {#066fb3c8 .cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_fruits.columns ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ``` Index(['apples', 'oranges'], dtype='object') ``` ::: ::: ::: {#f8b83791 .cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_fruits.index ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ``` Index(['Daniel', 'Sean', 'Pierce', 'Roger'], dtype='object') ``` ::: ::: ::: {#891e006e .cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_fruits.dtypes ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ``` apples int64 oranges int64 dtype: object ``` ::: ::: A `DataFrame` has many **methods** ::: {#d2ec2311 .cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_fruits.info() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Index: 4 entries, Daniel to Roger Data columns (total 2 columns): # Column Non-Null Count Dtype --- ------ -------------- ----- 0 apples 4 non-null int64 1 oranges 4 non-null int64 dtypes: int64(2) memory usage: 268.0+ bytes ``` ::: ::: ::: {#2ffab9a1 .cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_fruits.describe() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ```{=html}

Irwin Publishing. > You can also access this dataset now through the Python package Seaborn. ::: It contains data about a restaurant: the bill, tip and some informations about the customers. ::: {.callout-note} ### A toy extraction pattern A data pipeline usually starts with Extraction, that is gathering data from some source, possibly in a galaxy far, far awy. Here follows a toy extraction pattern - obtain the data from some `URL` using package `requests` - save the data on the hard drive - load the data using Pandas ::: {#efe1cead .cell execution_count=37} ``` {.python .cell-code} import requests import os # The path containing your notebook path_data = './' # The name of the file filename = 'tips.csv' if os.path.exists(os.path.join(path_data, filename)): print('The file %s already exists.' % os.path.join(path_data, filename)) else: url = 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mwaskom/seaborn-data/refs/heads/master/tips.csv' r = requests.get(url) with open(os.path.join(path_data, filename), 'wb') as f: f.write(r.content) print('Downloaded file %s.' % os.path.join(path_data, filename)) ``` ::: ::: {#1ad9e849 .cell execution_count=38} ``` {.python .cell-code} df = pd.read_csv( "tips.csv", delimiter="," ) ``` ::: ::: The data can be obtained from package `seaborn`. ::: {#a1aa9215 .cell execution_count=39} ``` {.python .cell-code} import seaborn as sns sns_ds = sns.get_dataset_names() 'tips' in sns_ds df = sns.load_dataset('tips') ``` ::: ::: {#ac275f18 .cell execution_count=40} ``` {.python .cell-code} # `.head()` shows the first rows of the dataframe df.head(n=10) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=37} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ::: ## Computations using `pandas` : broadcasting Let's add a column that contains the tip percentage ::: {#19114280 .cell execution_count=59} ``` {.python .cell-code} df["tip_percentage"] = df["tip"] / df["total_bill"] df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=56} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: The computation ```{{python}} df["tip"] / df["total_bill"] ``` uses a **broadcast** rule. - We can multiply, add, subtract, etc. together `numpy` arrays, `Series` or `pandas` dataframes when the computation **makes sense** in view of their respective **shape** This principle is called **broadcast** or **broadcasting**. ::: {.callout-note} Broadcasting is a key feature of `numpy` `ndarray`, see - [Numpy User's guide](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/user/basics.broadcasting.html) - [Pandas book](https://wesmckinney.com/book/advanced-numpy.html#numpy_broadcasting) ::: ::: {#a0bb3754 .cell execution_count=60} ``` {.python .cell-code} df["tip"].shape, df["total_bill"].shape ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=57} ``` ((244,), (244,)) ``` ::: ::: The `tip` and `total_bill`columns have the same `shape`, so broadcasting performs **pairwise division**. This corresponds to the following "hand-crafted" approach with a `for` loop: ::: {#5e976ff3 .cell execution_count=61} ``` {.python .cell-code} for i in range(df.shape[0]): df.loc[i, "tip_percentage"] = df.loc[i, "tip"] / df.loc[i, "total_bill"] ``` ::: But using such a loop is: - longer to write - less readable - prone to mistakes - and *slower* :( *NEVER* use `Python` for-loops unless you need to ! ::: {#a1765ea0 .cell execution_count=62} ``` {.python .cell-code} %%timeit -n 10 for i in range(df.shape[0]): df.loc[i, "tip_percentage"] = df.loc[i, "tip"] / df.loc[i, "total_bill"] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 23.4 ms ± 68.3 μs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10 loops each) ``` ::: ::: ::: {#b75800c9 .cell execution_count=63} ``` {.python .cell-code} %%timeit -n 10 df["tip_percentage"] = df["tip"] / df["total_bill"] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 71.2 μs ± 13.3 μs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10 loops each) ``` ::: ::: The `for` loop is $\approx$ **100 times slower** ! (even worse on larger data) ### Pitfall. Changing values in a `DataFrame` When you want to change a value in a `DataFrame`, never use ```python df["tip_percentage"].loc[i] = 42 ``` but use ```python df.loc[i, "tip_percentage"] = 42 ``` ::: {.callout-caution} Use a **single** `loc` or `iloc` statement. The first version **might not work**: it might modify a copy of the column and not the dataframe itself ! ::: Another example of broadcasting is: ::: {#d72a6170 .cell execution_count=64} ``` {.python .cell-code} (100 * df[["tip_percentage"]]).head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=61} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ## Supervised learning of `tip` based on the `total_bill` As an example of very simple **machine-learning** problem, let us try to understand how we can predict `tip` based on `total_bill`. ::: {#503ea9cd .cell execution_count=80} ``` {.python .cell-code} import numpy as np plt.scatter(df["total_bill"], df["tip"]) plt.xlabel("total_bill", fontsize=12) plt.ylabel("tip", fontsize=12) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=77} ``` Text(0, 0.5, 'tip') ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](notebook03_pandas_files/figure-html/cell-81-output-2.png){width=587 height=432} ::: ::: There's a rough **linear** dependence between the two. Let us try to find it by hand!
Namely, we look for numbers $b$ and $w$ such that ``` tip ≈ b + w × total_bill ``` for all the examples of pairs of `(tip, total_bill)` we observe in the data. In **machine learning**, we say that this is a very simple example of a **supervised learning** problem (here it is a regression problem), where `tip` is the **label** and where `total_bill` is the (only) **feature**, for which we intend to use a **linear predictor**. ::: {#d7494f89 .cell execution_count=81} ``` {.python .cell-code} plt.scatter(df["total_bill"], df["tip"]) plt.xlabel("total_bill", fontsize=12) plt.ylabel("tip", fontsize=12) slope = 1.0 intercept = 0.0 x = np.linspace(0, 50, 1000) plt.plot(x, intercept + slope * x, color="red") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](notebook03_pandas_files/figure-html/cell-82-output-1.png){width=587 height=432} ::: ::: ### A more interactive way This might require ::: {#106ffdfa .cell execution_count=82} ``` {.python .cell-code} # !pip install ipympl ``` ::: ::: {#62fa9ddc .cell execution_count=83} ``` {.python .cell-code} import ipywidgets as widgets import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import numpy as np %matplotlib widget %matplotlib inline x = np.linspace(0, 50, 1000) @widgets.interact(intercept=(-5, 5, 1.), slope=(0, 1, .05)) def update(intercept=0.0, slope=0.5): plt.scatter(df["total_bill"], df["tip"]) plt.plot(x, intercept + slope * x, color="red") plt.xlim((0, 50)) plt.ylim((0, 10)) plt.xlabel("total_bill", fontsize=12) plt.ylabel("tip", fontsize=12) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](notebook03_pandas_files/figure-html/cell-84-output-2.png){} ::: ::: This is kind of tedious to do this by hand... it would be nice to come up with an **automated** way of doing this. ``` ::: ::: ## One-hot encoding of categorical variables We can't perform computations (products and sums) with columns containing **categorical** variables. So, we can't use them like this to predict the `tip`. We need to **convert** them to numbers somehow. The most classical approach for this is **one-hot encoding** (or "create dummies" or "binarize") of the categorical variables, which can be easily achieved with `pandas.get_dummies` Why *one-hot* ? See [wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-hot) for a plausible explanation ::: {#7941af96 .cell execution_count=85} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_one_hot = pd.get_dummies(df, prefix_sep='#') df_one_hot.head(5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=82} ```{=html}

For instance, the `"day"` column is replaced by 4 columns named `"day#Thur"`, `"day#Fri"`, `"day#Sat"`, `"day#Sun"`, since `"day"` has 4 modalities (see next line). ::: {#22275502 .cell execution_count=86} ``` {.python .cell-code} df['day'].unique() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=83} ``` ['Sun', 'Sat', 'Thur', 'Fri'] Categories (4, object): ['Thur', 'Fri', 'Sat', 'Sun'] ``` ::: ::: ::: {#7749b800 .cell execution_count=87} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_one_hot.dtypes ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=84} ``` total_bill float64 tip float64 size int64 tip_percentage float64 sex#Male bool sex#Female bool smoker#Yes bool smoker#No bool day#Thur bool day#Fri bool day#Sat bool day#Sun bool time#Lunch bool time#Dinner bool dtype: object ``` ::: ::: ## Pitfall. Colinearities with one-hot encoding Sums over dummies for `sex`, `smoker`, `day`, `time` and `size` are all equal to one (by constrution of the one-hot encoded vectors). - Leads to **colinearities** in the matrix of features - It is **much harder** to train a linear regressor when the columns of the features matrix has colinearities ::: {#069af1e5 .cell execution_count=88} ``` {.python .cell-code} day_cols = [col for col in df_one_hot.columns if col.startswith("day")] df_one_hot[day_cols].head() df_one_hot[day_cols].sum(axis=1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=85} ``` 0 1 1 1 2 1 3 1 4 1 .. 239 1 240 1 241 1 242 1 243 1 Length: 244, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#ab6ec98e .cell execution_count=89} ``` {.python .cell-code} all(df_one_hot[day_cols].sum(axis=1) == 1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=86} ``` True ``` ::: ::: The most standard solution is to remove a modality (i.e. remove a one-hot encoding vector). Simply achieved by specifying `drop_first=True` in the `get_dummies` function. ::: {#99ce4f7d .cell execution_count=90} ``` {.python .cell-code} df["day"].unique() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=87} ``` ['Sun', 'Sat', 'Thur', 'Fri'] Categories (4, object): ['Thur', 'Fri', 'Sat', 'Sun'] ``` ::: ::: ::: {#fd86ae6c .cell execution_count=91} ``` {.python .cell-code} pd.get_dummies(df, prefix_sep='#', drop_first=True).head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=88} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: Now, if a categorical feature has $K$ modalities, we use only $K-1$ dummies. For instance, there is no more `sex#Female` binary column. **Question.** So, a linear regression won't fit a weight for `sex#Female`. But, where do the model weights of the dropped binary columns go ? **Answer.** They just "go" to the **intercept**: interpretation of the population bias depends on the "dropped" one-hot encodings. So, we actually fit: $$\begin{array}{rl} \texttt{tip} \approx b & + w_1 \times \texttt{total_bill} + w_2 \times \texttt{size} \\ & + w_3 \times \texttt{sex#Male} + w_4 \times \texttt{smoker#Yes} \\ & + w_5 \times \texttt{day#Sat} + w_6 \times \texttt{day#Sun} + w_7 \times \texttt{day#Thur} \\ & + w_8 \times \texttt{time#Lunch} \end{array}$$
